description: From Middle English assoilen (“to absolve (someone) of sin; to release (someone) from bonds of sin, hell, or purgatory; to absolve (a sin); to free (a country or someone) from an ecclesiastical offence or excommunication; to free (someone) from a criminal charge or sentence; to release (someone) from an obligation; to discharge (someone) from office; to exempt (someone) from service; to release (someone) from medical treatment; to answer (a question); to explain or solve (a problem, riddle, etc.); to fulfil (a promise); to disprove or refute (an argument)”) [and other forms], from Anglo-Norman as(s)oiler, as(s)oilier, and Old French as(s)oille [and other forms], the present subjunctive, and as(s)oil, the present indicative, of as(s)oldre, as(s)oudre (“to absolve from blame”) (modern French absoudre), from Latin absoluere, the present active infinitive of absoluō, a variant of absolvō (“to detach, loosen, untie; to liberate; (figuratively) to complete, finish; to pay off; (law) to declare innocent, absolve, acquit”), from ab- (prefix meaning ‘away, away from, from’) + solvō (“to loosen, undo, untie; to free up; to acquit; to exempt; to release”) (from sē- (“prefix meaning ‘apart; aside; away’”) + luō (“to wash; to cleanse; to purge”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *lewh₃- (“to wash”))). Doublet of absolve and assoilzie.

verbs.description: assoil (third-person singular simple present assoils, present participle assoiling, simple past and past participle assoiled) (transitive)

entries.meaning: To absolve or release (someone) from blame or sin; to forgive, to pardon.
(law) Followed by from or of: to acquit (someone) from a criminal charge; to find (someone) not guilty; to clear.
(archaic or obsolete) Followed by from or of: to release or set free (someone) from a liability, an obligation, etc.; to discharge.
To clear up or resolve (a difficulty, doubt, problem, etc.); to absolve, to solve.
To refute (an argument, an objection, etc.).
(rare) To discharge (a liability, an obligation, etc.).
(rare) To get rid of, put off, or remove (something).
(Christianity) To absolve or release (someone) from excommunication or some other religious offence.

description: Possibly from a- (intensifying prefix) or ad- (prefix meaning ‘to, toward’, or indicating an addition or tendency) +‎ soil (“to make dirty”), perhaps influenced by assoil (etymology 1).

verbs.description: assoil (third-person singular simple present assoils, present participle assoiling, simple past and past participle assoiled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic or obsolete) To make (something) dirty or soiled; to soil; to stain; to sully.
